Rich,
Hagihara-sensei and Tanobe-sensei seem to still be seen as the young guys in Japan.  I'm a little concerned about your point as well.  I asked about any younger people seriously studying fittings a few years ago and the reply was that they're only interested in clothes, cars and vacations.  Also, that nobody gets interested in antiques until they're fifty.  Certainly the people you mention got started younger than that.  Anyone have some more up to date information?
Jim 



  All, as an off topic on this, I was talking with a mate the other day on 
  the sad passing of Fujishiro sensei and how these great men are being 
  replaced. Cary Condell speaks very highly of Fujishiro Matsuo's son, 
  Fujishiro Okisato and I take him on his word on this matter. It is 
  wonderful to know this organization is in good hands. My friend and I 
  were also talking of other more "singular" giants of nihonto such as 
  Shibata Sensei and who his replacement would be in his business. This 
  led me to Hagihara Sensei, does he have a protege ?, who will replace 
  him when he passes on or retires ?. Is there much in the way of up and 
  coming's in line after the likes of Shibata, Tanobe and other sensei ?.

  Rich Turner
